revision.comment: /* Comparison between regional trade blocs */Typo fixing, replaced: de-facto → de facto using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Trade bloc}} {{Out of date|date=June 2011}} A '''trade bloc''' is a type of [[trade pact|intergovernmental agreement]], often part of a regional [[intergovernmental organization]], where regional [[barriers to trade]], ([[tariff]]s and [[Non-tariff barriers to trade|non-tariff barriers]]) are reduced or eliminated among the participating states.Schott 1991, 1. ==Description== [[File:Economic integration stages (World).png|thumb|350px|Stages of [[economic integration]] around the World:
(each country colored according to the most advanced [[trade pact|agreement]] that it participates into.) {{legend|#008000|[[Economic and Monetary Union]] ([[CARICOM Single Market and Economy|CSME]]/[[Eastern Caribbean Currency Union|EC$]], [[Economic and Monetary Union of the European Union|EU]]/[[Eurozone|€]])}} {{legend|#00FF00|[[Economic union]] ([[CARICOM Single Market and Economy|CSME]], [[Single market of the European Union|EU]])}} {{legend|#00FFFF|[[Customs and Monetary Union]] ([[Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa|CEMAC]]/[[Central African CFA franc|franc]], [[West African Economic and Monetary Union|UEMOA]]/[[West African CFA franc|franc]])}} {{legend|#804000|[[Common market]] ([[European Economic Area|EEA]], [[European Free Trade Association|EFTA]], [[Common Economic Space (CIS)|CES]])}} {{legend|#FF8040|[[Customs union]] ([[Andean Community|CAN]], [[Customs Union of Belarus, Kazakhstan and Russia|CUBKR]], [[East African Community|EAC]], [[European Union Customs Union|EUCU]], [[Southern Common Market|MERCOSUR]], [[Southern African Customs Union|SACU]])}} {{legend|#FF0000|[[List of multilateral free trade agreements|Multilateral Free Trade Area]] ([[ASEAN Free Trade Area|AFTA]], [[Central European Free Trade Agreement|CEFTA]], [[CISFTA]], [[Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa|COMESA]], [[Greater Arab Free Trade Area|GAFTA]], [[Gulf Cooperation Council|GCC]], [[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]], [[South Asia Free Trade Agreement|SAFTA]], [[Central American Integration System|SICA]], [[Trans-Pacific Strategic Economic Partnership|TPP]])}}]] One of the first economic blocs was the German Customs Union (''[[Zollverein]]'') initiated in 1834, formed on the basis of the [[German Confederation]] and subsequently [[German Empire]] from 1871. Surges of trade bloc formation were seen in the 1960s and 1970s, as well as in the 1990s after the [[collapse of Communism]]. By 1997, more than 50% of all world commerce was conducted under regional trade blocs.Milner 2002, 450. [[Economist]] Jeffrey J. Scott of the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] notes that members of successful trade blocs usually share four common traits: similar levels of per capita [[GNP]], geographic proximity, similar or compatible trading regimes, and political commitment to regional organization.Schott 1991, 2. Advocates of worldwide [[free trade]] are generally opposed to trading blocs, which, they argue, encourage regional as opposed to global free trade.O'Loughlin and Anselin 1996, 136. Scholars and economists continue to debate whether regional trade blocs are leading to a more fragmented world economy or encouraging the extension of the existing global [[Multilateralism|multilateral]] trading system.Milner 2002, 458.Mansfield and Milner 2005, 330. Trade blocs can be stand-alone agreements between several states (such as the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) or part of a [[regional organization]] (such as the [[European Union]]). Depending on the level of [[economic integration]], trade blocs can fall into different categories, such as:Mansfield and Milner 2005, 333. [[preferential trading area]]s, [[free trade area]]s, [[customs union]]s, [[common market]]s and [[economic and monetary union]]s. ==Lists of trade blocs== [[Image:Currency union.PNG|thumb|right|350px|[[Currency union|Monetary unions]].]] [[Image:Customs unions.png|thumb|right|350px|[[Customs unions]] worldwide.]] [[File:Trade blocs.png|thumb|350px|Regional [[Trade block|trade blocs]]:{{legend|#0000FF|[[European Union]] (EU)}} {{legend|#804000|[[African Union]] (AU)}} {{legend|#FF8040|[[Union of South American Nations]] (UNASUR)}} {{legend|#FFFF00|[[Caribbean Community]] (CARICOM)}} {{legend|#FF00FF|[[Central American Integration System]] (SICA)}} {{legend|#FF0000|[[Arab League]] (AL)}} {{legend|#800000|[[European Free Trade Association]] (EFTA)}} {{legend|#008000|[[Eurasian Economic Community]] (EAEC)}} {{legend|#00FFFF|[[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN)}} {{legend|#8000FF|[[Central European Free Trade Agreement]] (CEFTA)}} {{legend|#8080FF|[[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA)}} {{legend|#808000|[[South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation]] (SAARC)}} {{legend|#00FF00|[[Pacific Islands Forum]] (PIF)}}]] * [[List of preferential trade areas]] * [[List of free trade areas]] ([[List of bilateral free trade agreements|bilateral]], [[List of multilateral free trade agreements|multilateral]]) * [[List of customs unions]] * [[List of common markets]] * [[List of economic unions]] * [[List of monetary unions]] * [[List of customs and monetary unions]] * [[List of economic and monetary unions]]
